numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I noticed a graph.
2. In the graph, people who are 15 years old to 24 years old generally believe that the world is becoming better with each generation.
3. In the graph, people who are 40 years old generally believe this less often.
4. This graph confuses me.
5. The graph does not send a clear message.
6. The graph does not show a general trend for different types of countries.
7. I noticed that several African countries have high percentages in both age groups.
8. I noticed that several Asian countries have high percentages in both age groups.
9. I noticed that several European countries have lower percentages in both age groups.
10. I noticed that several South American countries have lower percentages in both age groups.
11. I am curious about the author of the graph.
12. The author chose only 21 countries.
13. The author did not include many age groups.
14. A 15-year-old person is very different from a 24-year-old person.
15. The data set is small.
16. The data set includes 21000 people in all countries.
17. This graph relates to my community.
18. In my community, there is a stigma about recent generations.
19. The stigma says that recent generations are more lazy than older generations.
20. This stigma might cause a low percentage of 40-year-old people to think that generations have been getting better.
21. I ask whether geography changes the views of different generations about each other.
